- HARDWRAPS: Alternative handling of newlines, see Github-flavoured-Markdown
- AUTOLINKS: Plain (undelimited) autolinks the way Github-flavoured-Markdown implements them.
- FENCED CODE BLOCKS: Fenced Code Blocks in the way of PHP Markdown Extra or Github-flavoured-Markdown.

. As far as I know this would be possible if we had a proper PSI tree built. idea-markdown is a hack, we have no lexing/parsing, we just use an external annotator to defer syntax highlighting to the underlying library.
It seems to be big work to me, but my knowledge of the IDEA API is pretty limited, so if you want to experiment on this I will be happy to help you !
Did you take a look at idea-markdown implementation ? Do you think it's doable ?
. The difficulty with Markdown is that it does not fit well in ANTLR-style parsing model (because of references/abbreviations/etc). idea-markdown uses a PEG-style parser under the hood, which is difficult to adapt to IntelliJ's PSI building API... I didn't know about their grammar kit, maybe this can make the bridge between both worlds ?
(cc @gregsh)

todofixthis:
Requirements
This issue doesn't appear to have requirements ATM.  May I suggest:
- The most important feature that I would like to see come from this is using headings (#, ##, etc.) as major sections in structure view.
- Bonus points if e.g., the first 30 or so characters from each paragraph appear as leaves so that I can locate content if I've forgotten or do not know which section it appears in.
Example
Markdown

# Heading 1
## Subheading 2
Bacon ipsum dolor sit amet aliqua ea elit deserunt qui chuck. Meatloaf mollit tail do id pariatur. Tail exercitation non kielbasa quis corned beef. Nisi short loin proident eiusmod, flank deserunt id officia do. Ex pastrami bresaola, officia adipisicing deserunt occaecat meatball pork chop pork sint cillum excepteur tongue jowl. Nulla ut short loin, chicken ut in culpa. Sirloin cillum incididunt tenderloin occaecat ut cow fugiat, beef venison chuck enim tempor id aliqua.

Irure consectetur non deserunt in boudin, tri-tip jerky nisi. Elit fugiat corned beef beef ribs tail salami. Adipisicing beef incididunt, in culpa magna ea ball tip corned beef short ribs eiusmod kielbasa biltong shoulder. Voluptate pariatur short ribs laboris ut, hamburger shoulder fugiat bacon ground round ribeye. Drumstick bacon reprehenderit rump, flank deserunt sunt pariatur cupidatat chicken. Boudin pork belly excepteur voluptate shoulder meatloaf. Meatloaf ut pork belly ham beef, do venison officia ut reprehenderit andouille.

## Subheading 3
Sausage magna prosciutto, incididunt ut beef ribs cupidatat laborum ham hock. Ullamco capicola andouille shank jowl. Mollit ad capicola, occaecat boudin aliquip anim eiusmod id brisket. Nisi exercitation in, t-bone beef labore velit frankfurter. Id ground round dolore, filet mignon shankle meatloaf consectetur brisket bacon biltong hamburger eu velit ut. Shank shankle nostrud enim, exercitation magna veniam spare ribs. Duis pariatur drumstick, sirloin non irure fugiat exercitation aute chuck short ribs ex excepteur occaecat aliquip.

# Heading 4

sirthias:
Enabling all extension may be a bit too much as a default settings.
While most pegdown extensions do not change to original markdown syntax one does: "HARDWRAPS".
If you enable this extension pegdown will behave like github and not like the original markdown, something that might be unexpected to new users. IMHO it'd be better to have Extensions.ALL & ~Extensions.HARDWRAPS as the default setting (at least until the plugin allows for user-level enabling/disabling of pegdown options through a plugin configuration pane).

borisdiakur:
In https://github.com/nicoulaj/idea-markdown/issues/138#issuecomment-42680755 @denofevil mentions that you can make use of the editorconfig plugin, which by now is a bundled one. Here is what you would put into the .editorconfig file:
[*.{md,markdown}]
trim_trailing_whitespace = false
. Using an .editorconfig file works for me.
[*.{md,markdown}]
trim_trailing_whitespace = false

wrote:

Just a thought, but GitHub does offer an API endpoint
https://developer.github.com/v3/markdown/ to render "GitHub flavored
Markdown".
They also offer a Ruby Gem https://rubygems.org/gems/github-markdown
packaged for local reuse. This of course would require an embedded Ruby
run-time - Koala http://koala-app.com/, for example, has a minimal Ruby
run-time embedded, which doesn't even bloat the distribution (much) and
guarantees a safe, easy, direct upgrade-path to future versions of GitHub's
Markdown.
I mean to suggest that there are much simpler/easier ways to get to full
support for Markdown without relying on a third-party implementation. The
number of users submitting +1's for GitHub Markdown suggest this may be
what most users are longing for, although I suppose it's possible this
project is aiming for broader/generic Markdown support? I don't know how
you would address the potential number of proprietary Markdown extensions
in practice though - might be better to just settle for one, the most
popular one, if that's GitHub...

mindplay-dk:
Just a thought, but GitHub does offer an API endpoint to render "GitHub flavored Markdown".
They also offer a Ruby Gem packaged for local reuse. This of course would require an embedded Ruby run-time - Koala, for example, has a minimal Ruby run-time embedded, which doesn't even bloat the distribution (much) and guarantees a safe, easy, direct upgrade-path to future versions of GitHub's Markdown.
I mean to suggest that there are much simpler/easier ways to get to full support for Markdown without relying on a third-party implementation. The number of users submitting +1's for GitHub Markdown suggest this may be what most users are longing for, although I suppose it's possible this project is aiming for broader/generic Markdown support? I don't know how you would address the potential number of proprietary Markdown extensions in practice though - might be better to just settle for one, the most popular one, if that's GitHub...
. > afaik http://commonmark.org/ offers a c implementaion, maybe also java.
Again, you will be relying on a third party to keep up with any changes made to the official GitHub implementation, as well as (obviously) getting it right in the first place.
. > looks like this gem is not pure ruby
Yeah, looks like the Ruby part is just a thin interface to a C library. That's probably a terrible idea then. Unless maybe it's possible to build the C library using Emscripten? Of course porting it would take some footwork.
Another thought is to let the browser do the work, e.g. using a JS library like marked which seems to have good support for GitHub flavor already.
.

holgerbrandl:
You're totally right. Once you've a PSI tree it's a snap. But without it's not doable afaik. I've just learned about MarkDown when looking into knitr, so my understanding of it is too limited to write a parser. What helped me a lot to create a psi-parser for R was to use the grammar kit extension (https://github.com/JetBrains/Grammar-Kit)
.
gregsh:
Grammar-Kit takes PEG grammar and produces PsiBuilder-based parser and PSI classes. Parboiled-to-BNF conversion should be pretty straightforward but lexer extraction (at least a simple whitespace/word tokenizer) will take some time because unlike other PEG parsers Grammar-Kit requires a lexer which is required by PsiBuilder API actually. Feel free to ask more questions if you decide to take this road.

. It was specifically disabled in the plugin. For Markdown files trailing spaces can be significant. GitHub's Hard Wrap option makes this not essential but this feature was specifically requested.
. The issue is with the file type returned by scratch files. Regular files will have the markdown file type. Scratch files do not. To get the file type of the scratch file you need to request this information from the scratch file service. So idea-markdown does not recognize scratch files as markdown.
You can see the code I use in idea-multimarkdown plugin, which is an overhauled and enhanced version of idea-markdown. The code to handle this can be seen here: https://github.com/vsch/idea-multimarkdown/blob/master/src/main/java/com/vladsch/idea/multimarkdown/editor/MultiMarkdownPreviewEditorProvider.java#L58-L61
. I forked this plug-in, merged a couple of pull requests, made a few bug corrections and added live preview with customizable CSS in settings to make it easier to play with the styles. I decided to release the forked version as a new plug-in since this one seems to be lacking attention.
It is called MultiMarkdown and is awaiting approval from JetBrains but can be found at https://plugins.jetbrains.com/plugin/7896, source available at: http://github.com/vsch/idea-multimarkdown.
. I just fixed and updated the syntax highlighting, if anyone cares to try it out. It also has an HTML tab.

. It is a bug in the old version of pegdown parser that this plugin uses.
I forked this plugin and updated to latest pegdown, fixed its list parsing bugs and added options. Made it look almost like GitHub's markdown.
Current version of my plugin has syntax highlighting broken, the fix will be available tomorrow. I have it working as it was in idea-markdown but it is very limited. Syntax highlighting for inlines does not work in lists, tables, etc. Only in plain paragraphs. 
I am working on a temporary quick-fix that will be acceptable until I can write a lexer as expected by IntelliJ. The plugin is called MultiMarkdown check it out and let me know what you think.
. Turn on the Fenced code blocks in settings / Other Settings / Mardown. Fenced code blocks are an extension to Markdown, by default all extensions are turned off.

. Thank you for reporting this. Sorry, but I did not see it sooner. idea-multimarkdown lives at https://github.com/vsch/idea-multimarkdown. This repository is of the original idea-markdown plugin.
I'll try to duplicate it in Ubuntu, but it looks like JavaFX crash during initialization. I had this in early versions but did not have the issue come up on the Mac since then. It is a crash in JavaFX native libraries, probably due to a bug in JavaFX or WebView.
The workaround is to select 'Use Old Preview' in Settings > Other Settings > MultiMarkdown
To avoid the crash you need to open PyCharm without opening a project with a markdown file opened so that it does not try to create a JavaFX preview tab. This is a pain because all IDEA's will restart with the previously opened project. Two ways around it:
1. Quickly hit the space bar or the cancel button on the progress dialog that is opening the initial project on start-up. Go into settings and select 'Use Old Preview'
2. Manually delete idea-multimarkdown from the application cache directory for PyCharm so that it comes up with MultiMarkdown uninstalled. When you re-install it, make sure there are no open multi-markdown files in the project or install it without any projects open. On restart, open settings and select 'Use Old Preview' checkbox.
I will let you know how it goes with duplicating it on Ubuntu on my system.
. I created an issue in vsch/idea-multimarkdown#42, I will post updates there. 
. @damluar, PlantUML requires that the source be sent to the server for processing and the image URL replaced with a server generated one. Gravizo lets you specify the UML in the image src tag so that no pre-processing is necessary.
It appears that this plugin has been abandoned by its author. So I doubt new features such as PlantUML support will be added, unless someone does it and releases it as a new plugin. That was my motivation for forking this project and releasing it as new plugin. Otherwise there was no way to make the updated version available to anyone but me.
I don't know how compatible is the syntax of PlantUML and Gravizo gravizo is another option for server generated UML. Unfortunately the swing image rendering used by this plugin does not handle the images returned from gravizo so even that is not a solution. 
I was only able to make the preview work in my plugin: idea-multimarkdown on  GitHub and idea-multimarkdown JetBrains plugin page in the JavaFX WebView preview and only by using the HTML img instead of the markdown image link syntax. In all cases the swing based preview complained about the image format, so it was not usable.
Here is a split screen view of source and preview of gravizo generated images:

. @petrkotek the plugin tries to resolve any link it cannot resolve to a file as a Java class name. It does it without checking to see if the IDE has indexes up to date. If it doesn't then you will get an exception. 
This project has been abandoned by its owner, so with each new IntelliJ release it keeps having more issues.
You should try my plugin vsch/idea-multimarkdown it started as a fork of this plugin so I could fix a few bugs and improve the look of the preview.  That was five months ago. Now it is a completely different plugin, with JavaFX WebView preview true GitHub like rendering. I also make  regular releases to fix bugs and add features that are requested. 
Give it a try and let me know what you think. 
. @nyxee, comment update for the link vsch/idea-multimarkdown

split editor for text and preview. Preview can be:
rendered HTML
with syntax highlighting with HighlightJS or Prism.js

highlighting of rendered HTML element as caret moves on it in source document
navigate to source by clicking on element in preview


HTML used for rendering,
plain HTML as converted from markdown

configuration
per project code style and syntax highlighting configuration
per project and per scope:
preview,
rendering,
stylesheet options,
html generation options,
link mapping
html export options




navigation:
to all referenced and referencing types in text
with line markers
auto-scroll to element under caret in text in preview (rendered and html text) and highlight it briefly
move caret to element in text by clicking on the element in preview
bread crumbs for markdown element hierarchy
structure view
from links in rendered HTML to the corresponding files on GitHub


refactoring:
files, links, headings, anchor refs, references and ref links and images
file move refactoring of links, image links and wiki links
in upcoming release refactoring of permalink: in Jekyll front matter


completions:
link, wiki link and image addresses to files,
link, wiki link and image text based on link address
anchor refs to headings,
ref links and images to references
GitHub issue # in text and in issues/ links
language for fenced code

inline code completion to Java classes their fields and members
emoji shortcuts, all of the Emoji-Cheat-Sheet.com :smile: 


language injections so you can see it syntax highlighted and edit the fragment in a separate window, with full IDE support for that language.
fenced code, automatic if language is provided, requires selection of language otherwise
HTML blocks
indented code (requires selecting language to inject)
Jekyll front matter block


Creature comforts that make life easier:
auto format of document with options on element style for rendered elements and arranging non-rendering ones.
auto format table with justification
wrap on typing, handlers for typing, back space and enter
use actual character width for text reflow in format, wrap on typing and table justification. For better support for non-latin content

inspections:

links to files in same repo on GitHub that are only local

mixed list item types in a list (numbers vs. bullets)

incorrect emoji shortcuts


intentions to fix what inspections found and:

toggle task item done/undone


toolbar:

oops... Sorry Nicoula, I didn't see the earlier issue.
. Rebuilding from the source for your particular Idea version resolves the issue.

3. install the idea-markdown.zip produced in the root folder of the project.

cebartling:
From the RubyMine log file, it looks like the class file version is not supported when running RubyMine 4.5.4 with JDK 1.6.0_37:
java.lang.UnsupportedClassVersionError: net/nicoulaj/idea/markdown/editor/MarkdownPreviewEditorProvider : Unsupported major.minor version 51.0
Was the plugin compiled with Java 7?  Removing the plugin directory from ~/Library/Application Support/RubyMine40 resolves any issues with RubyMine.  Seems like a showstopper issue here.
. Unfortunately, JetBrains IDEs (IntelliJ IDEA, RubyMine, Webstorm, etc.) are not certified on Java 7 runtimes at this point in time.  Therefore, plugin developers should always be targeting the class file runtime that JetBrains certifies on (which is current Java 6).  Look under System Requirements for any of the Java-based tools.
.

panique:
+1 in PHPStorm 8. *.md is clearly bound to Markdown plugin (in File Types). But I found the problem: PHPStorm seems to add readme.md to text files more or less automatically (probably an unintended click on a file type parser suggestion popup long time ago). Removing this from text files in File Types fixes the problem.
.

xinitrc:
YAML Front Matter is a initial YAML ("YAML Ain't Markup Language") part in beginning of a Markdown file this is common e.g. in Markdown Blog Posts in systems like Jekyll or Hakyll an example can be found e.g. in my blogs github repositoy: 
https://raw.github.com/xinitrc/xinitrc.de/master/posts/2013-08-01-Activity-monitor.md

ReservedDeveloper:
Bump on this request. YAML Front Matter is pretty hard to avoid in the realm of SSGs (Static Site Generators) based on Markdown content. I'm currently working on a project using such a tool and have had to opt for a separate editor to avoid lots of rendering anomalies. Would love to see this feature introduced!

Sending Message to the Page from a Chrome extension
A Chrome extension may pass information to the page as follows.
The basic pattern is:
Background Page -> Content Script -> Page
|                               |       |
+------- Chrome Extension ------+       |
                                        |
                          Webapp Frontend

Example of the extension's background page invoking the Chrome Extension API and sending
idle event notifications to the content script, which forwards it to the webapp:
```javascript
// background.js - CRX background page
// Receives event notifications from the Chrome Extension API and forwards them to the content script (page.js)
chrome.idle.onStateChanged.addListener(
    function(newState) {
        chrome.tabs.getSelected(null, function(tab) {
            chrome.tabs.sendMessage(tab.id, { command: 'someCommand', newState: newState });
        });
    }
);
// page.js - CRX content script
// Receives a message from background.js and forwards it to the web page
chrome.extension.onMessage.addListener(function(request, sender, sendResponse) {
    window.postMessage(request, '*');
});
// webapp frontend
// Receives a forwarded message from page.js
window.addEventListener('message', function(event) {
    // Do something
});
```

Mike-T-Mitchell:
I know this is closed, but I'm wondering if there's any update on MD compatibility with WebStorm 9 on the horizon? 
Thanks for your time =)
. Ah, my apologies for asking the question without following up:
I managed to get this working last night — When I went to "plugins," and searched for "Markdown" and nothing was returned. It wasn't until I created the README.md file and saved it that WS9 said displayed a modal saying "Markdown is supported via plugin, would you like to download this now?"
After downloading, installing, and restarting WS, the plugin worked fine. I'm not sure why I couldn't install it myself via the Plugins search functionality, but it's working now, so no complaints from me.
Thank you for your time!
--Mitch

szarouski:
@Mike-T-Mitchell plugin works just fine for me on WS9.
. In Webstorm 9.0.2 I added following to my .editorconfig file and it stopped stripping out whitespace only for markdown files.
[*.md]
trim_trailing_whitespace = false
.

Ugoku:
Confirmed, also on Windows 8.1.
This causes the Project view (Alt-1) not to load any files. Disabling this plugin fixes that.
.
sam-vmware:
In the latest IDEA EAP the exception also prevents project tree expansion so the plugin needs to be disable for the time being.
.
bjansen:
But it breaks backward compatibility with previous versions of IDEA/WebStorm/... And currently, "previous versions" mean "current version" because it's only broken in EAP versions.
Perhaps some reflection could be used to retrieve the correct constant?
. You're right, conditional imports don't work. In fact I was thinking of something like:
Object theField = Class.forName("com.intellij.openapi.fileEditor.impl.TrailingSpacesStripper").getDeclaredField("OVERRIDE_STRIP_TRAILING_SPACES_KEY").get(null);
And depending on the detected version, you just have to change the package name. It's kind of ugly, but it allows distributing a single plugin for multiple target versions. Otherwise, as you mentioned it's possible to restrict min/max versions of IntelliJ that are supported by the plugin, but you'll have to maintain 2 different versions (although it's quite easy with branches).
. Don't forget that people don't necessarily buy each new version of their IDE. Perhaps they want to benefit from idea-markdown's updates as well, but it won't be possible if you set a min version (e.g. 8). They will be stuck with an older version of the plugin.
.
brodock:
As far as I know, there is no way to do a "conditional import", you will have to conditionally use the "full qualified name" and then conditionally use one or another.
I don't know Jetbrains Plugin API enough, but, isn't possible to restrict version for plugin updates, like we do with rubygems, debian packages, etc? You can start a new 0.10.x that requires at least X version, and continue to release updates to the 0.9.x for older versions?
.
Anahkiasen:
Would you actually need to maintain the older version ? I mean 8 will become stable soon and it's not like the package changes that often, if the older version works, just lock it and do future improvements for 8+ no ?
.
valich:
I incline to the "ugly" solution because maintaining two different branches is not so hard, but is also not what one may dream of. One would need to have a different plugin.xml for every version (that complicates making any changes to plugin.xml), would need to upload plugin twice.. and maybe something more, depending on the users inventiveness.
I have made some corrections to the pull request, tested in Idea 13/14, WebStorm 8/9. Everything seems to be okay now.
.
hailwood:
Is there any reason we can't just limit the plugin version to this eap+ with a note to older users to manually download version X from the website? 
If those users have made a decision to stick with a previous version I would be inclined to say getting the correct version of the plugin should be their responsibility instead of us bloating the plugin.
.

tflori:
my suggestion would be something like this:
a configuration: "enable post processing on save for syntax supported files"
syntax supported files (like php in phpstorm): "post processing on save configuration tab -> trim trailing spaces (boolean)"
other files: post processing on save configuration
a plugin like markdown can then add syntax support for markdown and have it's own rules for post processing on save. another feature: each syntax can have their own features - for example: force replace tabs by spaces for python files etc... or even reformat code for specific syntax.
this will be a more general solution than just ignore the setting magically for markdown files..
but anyway for now I'm using the solution by szarouski thx.

2015-10-06 12:57 GMT+02:00 Vladimir Schneider notifications@github.com:

Thank you for reporting this. Sorry, but I did not see it sooner.
idea-multimarkdown lives at https://github.com/vsch/idea-multimarkdown.
This repository is of the original idea-markdown plugin.
I'll try to duplicate it in Ubuntu, but it looks like JavaFX crash during
initialization. I had this in early versions but did not have the issue
come up on the Mac since then. It is a crash in JavaFX native libraries,
probably due to a bug in JavaFX or WebView.
The workaround is to select 'Use Old Preview' in Settings > Other
Settings > MultiMarkdown
To avoid the crash you need to open PyCharm without opening a project with
a markdown file opened so that it does not try to create a JavaFX preview
tab. This is a pain because all IDEA's will restart with the previously
opened project. Two ways around it:
1.
Quickly hit the space bar or the cancel button on the progress dialog
   that is opening the initial project on start-up. Go into settings and
   select 'Use Old Preview'
   2.
Manually delete idea-multimarkdown from the application cache
   directory for PyCharm so that it comes up with MultiMarkdown uninstalled.
   When you re-install it, make sure there are no open multi-markdown files in
   the project or install it without any projects open. On restart, open
   settings and select 'Use Old Preview' checkbox.
I will let you know how it goes with duplicating it on Ubuntu on my system.
—
